Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is based on a misapplication of a federal statute and does not consider the specific circumstances of the act.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that tearing up a copy of the State of the Union address constitutes a violation of 18 U.S.C. § 2071 without considering the intent and context of the act.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Pelosi ripped up her own copy of the address, not the official version sent to the National Archives.
Understate: The claim may understate the complexity and interpretation of the federal statute, as legal experts argue that it is not applicable in this particular case.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation that tearing up a copy of the State of the Union address does not fall under the scope of the federal statute, as it is not a government record filed or deposited with any clerk or officer.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by misapplying the federal statute and not considering the specific circumstances and intent of the act.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the potential consequences by stating that the violation is punishable by up to three years in prison without considering the specific circumstances and intent of the act.
